post: 📜  #OTD in 1787, Federalist No. 1 was published, the first of 85 essays by Hamilton, Madison, and Jay defending the Constitution. How can these essays help students see the importance of debate in shaping a free society? 🔗 Lesson:  https://bit.ly/42WkFvd  #TDiH  #FederalistPapers  #CivicEducation  #AmericanHistory  #SelfGovernment

Close October strong. Log 1 activity by Friday to get your class in the Civic Star Challenges first round. It takes minutes, and youll keep building entries all year. 🔗  https://bit.ly/3V1CQuX  #CivicStarChallenge  #CivicEducation  #TeachingResources  #America250

These Constitutions go very fast! Feedback from principals, teachers, and parents has been extremely positive as they encourage kids to learn and truly understand the scope & spirit of our founding documents.   John B., Pennsylvania educator $1 = 1 Pocket Constitution:  https://bit.ly/40EsBAg  #CivicsChampion  #CivicEducation  #TeacherVoices  #SupportTeachers

What made the Monroe Doctrine a cornerstone of early U. S. foreign policy? This Primary Source Essentials episode unpacks Monroes 1823 address, warning Europe against colonization while shaping Americas role in the Western Hemisphere. 🎥 Watch now:  https://bit.ly/4oEBd3r  #PrimarySources  #CivicEducation  #AmericanHistory  #ForeignPolicy

At the Bill of Rights Institute, we believe civic life begins with small, human acts of connection. In her recent Wall Street Journal op-ed, Rachel Davison Humphries, BRIs Senior Director of Civic Learning Initiatives, reminds us that even something as simple as turning on a porch light and greeting a child on Halloween can strengthen democracy. Halloween, she writes, is one of our last democratic rituals,  a moment when trust, courage, and community come alive on neighborhood streets. Read Halloween Treats for Democracy  in The Wall Street Journal:  https://on.wsj.com/42Ur4qM  #Halloween  #CivicEducation  #Democracy  #Community  #Leadership  #CivicEngagement

How do teachers bring civic engagement to life? This AP Government teacher shares how her students explored representation in Congress through a Civic Star Challenge lesson, connecting civics to real-world decision-making. 🎥 Watch the clip and join the challenge:  https://bit.ly/3V1CQuX  #CivicStarChallenge  #CivicEducation  #Teachers  #CivicEngagement

From community gardens to literacy programs, students nationwide are proving that civic ideas work. Join hundreds of students creating change through the MyImpact Challenge, where service meets leadership. 🔗 Enter or share:  https://bit.ly/3fyGGr3  #MyImpactChallenge  #CivicLeadership  #StudentVoice  #CivicEngagement

How did democracy expand, and what challenges came with it, in the early 1800s? Our new middle school lesson, America in Transition, uses George Caleb Binghams County Election to explore freedom, equality, and civic virtue in a changing nation. 🎥 Watch now:  https://bit.ly/4hjhrI5  #CivicEducation  #AmericanHistory  #MiddleSchool

Congratulations to National Civics Teacher of the Year finalist Elizabeth Purtell (Heritage Academy, AZ)! She equips 8th graders with sourcing, bias-spotting, and civil discourse skills, then channels them into real civic action. Read Elizabeths spotlight:  https://bit.ly/47azL2V  #CivicEducation  #StudentVoice
